sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Consider the following system of linear equations:
\
\begin{align*}
4x_1 + 2x_2 &= 20, \\
2x_1 + 2x_2 &= 10, \\
3x_1 + 5x_2 &= 25.
\end{align*}
\
Write this system as a block matrix equation and solve for the vector $\mathbf{x}=(x_1,x_2)^T$.
message_2:
We can write the given system of linear equations as a block matrix equation in the form $\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}$, where $\mathbf{A}$ is the matrix of coefficients, $\mathbf{x}$ is the column vector of variables, and $\mathbf{b}$ is the column vector of constants.

In this case, we have:

$$
\mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix}
4 & 2 \\
2 & 2 \\
3 & 5
\end{bmatrix},
\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2
\end{bmatrix},
\mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix}
20 \\
10 \\
25
\end{bmatrix}.
$$

So the block matrix equation is:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
4 & 2 \\
2 & 2 \\
3 & 5
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
20 \\
10 \\
25
\end{bmatrix}.
$$

Since $\mathbf{A}$ is not a square matrix, we cannot use the inverse matrix method to solve for $\mathbf{x}$. Instead, we can use the least squares method to find the best approximate solution. The normal equations for the least squares method are given by:

$$
\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{b}.
$$

First, we compute $\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{b}$:

$$
\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix}
4 & 2 & 3 \\
2 & 2 & 5
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
4 & 2 \\
2 & 2 \\
3 & 5
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
29 & 21 \\
21 & 29
\end{bmatrix},
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix}
4 & 2 & 3 \\
2 & 2 & 5
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
20 \\
10 \\
25
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
110 \\
90
\end{bmatrix}.
$$

Now we have a new system of linear equations:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
29 & 21 \\
21 & 29
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
110 \\
90
\end{bmatrix}.
$$

We can solve this system using the inverse matrix method. First, we find the inverse of the matrix $\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{A}$:

$$
(\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{A})^{-1} = \frac{1}{(29)(29) - (21)(21)} \begin{bmatrix}
29 & -21 \\
-21 & 29
\end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{116} \begin{bmatrix}
29 & -21 \\
-21 & 29
\end{bmatrix}.
$$

Now we can find the solution vector $\mathbf{x}$:

$$
\mathbf{x} = (\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{A})^{-1}\mathbf{A}^T\mathbf{b} = \frac{1}{116} \begin{bmatrix}
29 & -21 \\
-21 & 29
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
110 \\
90
\end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{116} \begin{bmatrix}
(29)(110) - (21)(90) \\
(-21)(110) + (29)(90)
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
2 \\
3
\end{bmatrix}.
$$

So the best approximate solution for the given system of linear equations is:

$$
\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
2 \\
3
\end{bmatrix}.
$$
